thread.title: Stoupa, Greece: Secret Seaside

author: Jane Foster
title: Stoupa, Greece: Secret Seaside
text: Mountainous and relatively inaccessible, Greeks consider the Mani peninsular to be wild and remote. In the Outer Mani, set amid olive groves, Stoupa sits below the rocky peaks of the Taygetos mountain range, whose highest point, Profitis Ilias, soars 2407 m (7896 ft). Built around three sheltered turquoise bays, Stoupa offers a peaceful retreat from modern day life, and plenty of inspiration to delve into the ancient myths of gods and nymphs, and the tales of medieval tower houses and blood feuds for which the region is notorious. For most Grecophiles, the neighbouring village of Kardamyli (4 miles up the coast) is better known. For many years home to the British travel writer and adventurer Patrick Leigh Fermor (1915-2011), author of the highly recomended Mani: Travels in the South Peloponnese, Kardamyli is certainly prettier, with its old stone cottages and cafes clustered around a central square, overlooked by Upper Kardamyli, now deserted but posing a timeless image, with its medieval tower houses, 18th-century church and cypresses, perched up on the hillside, high above the coast. But the beaches at Stoupa are infinitely better. Made up of low-rise white modern concrete buildings, Stoupa focuses on the sea, with the main road south to Areopolis running behind the village, leaving it slow-paced and sun-beaten. The main beach is a broad stretch of pale sand, lying in a wide sweeping bay, lined with sun beds and umbrellas, and backed by a promenade with bars, cafes and restaurants. It’s popular with families with kids, and offers peddle-boats and canoes for hire, but can get busy in peak season. A 10-minute walk north from here, the lovely Kalogria beach sits in sheltered cove backed by tamarisk and palm trees, and has three informal tavernas. There’s a beach volleyball court on the golden sand, and the PADI-approved Dive Code scuba centre ( divecodegreece.com ) is based here. For something quieter, you might hike another 10 minutes north of Stoupa to Delfinia beach, a crescent of small grey pebbles backed by a lush olive grove – it’s a great spot for snorkeling, but the sea bed drops suddenly, so it gets very deep, making it unsuitable for small children. • Koufonissia, Greece: Secret Seaside • Karavostási, Greece: Secret Seaside Visit out of season for the best experience Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Moving inland to the windswept rugged mountains, you’ll find well-marked hiking paths leading through rocky herb-scented landscapes and rural villages to lonesome Byzantine churches and beyond. For a good one-day hike, tackle the Viros Gorge, which runs down to Kardamyli (12mi round route, 6-7 hours), taking you through woodland, up onto rocky tracks, and then down into the steep-sided gorge, where huge white boulders are scattered along the dry torrent bed. Be sure to carry plenty of water and wear good hiking shoes. Adventure sports specialists 2407 ( 2407m.com ) run organised hikes and hire out mountain bikes, and can also supply maps and local advice, should you choose to go it alone. Excursions further afield from Stoupa include the Diros Cave (29mi) near Areopolis, which you can enter by boat to see a huge cavern filled with spectacular stalactites and stalagmites, and Mystra (59mi), a fortified Byzantine town built into a steep hillside with half a dozen churches, now proclaimed a UNESCO world heritage site. • Kea, Greece: Secret Seaside • Voutoumi, Greece: Secret Seaside The main beach is a broad stretch of pale sand, lying in a wide sweeping bay Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Getting there Through summer, EasyJet (0330 365 5000; easyjet.com ) flies to Kalamata from London Gatwick, and Thomas Cook (01733 224 808; thomascook.com/flights ) from Birmingham, London Gatwick and Manchester. Thanks to the opening of the Corinth-Kalamata motorway, completed in March 2015, the Mani has become easier to reach from Athens. You can fly to Athens with British Airways (0844 493 0787; britishairways.com ) from London Heathrow; Aegean Airlines (00 30 210 626 1000; aegeanair.com ) from London Heathrow, London Gatwick or Manchester; or Ryanair (0871 246 0000, ryanair.com ) from London Stansted. Moving inland to the windswept rugged mountains, you’ll find well-marked hiking paths leading through rocky herb-scented landscapes Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Where to stay Kalogria Beach Hotel € Located right on Kalogria beach, this friendly family-run hotel prides itself on the number of visitors who return each year. It offers double-height studios and family apartments sleeping four, complete with kitchenettes and balconies, as well as more simple rooms, plus a good restaurant. (0030 27210 77479; kalogria-beach.gr ; doubles from €TK) Villa Kosta € Just a two-minute walk from Stoupa’s main beach, Villa Kosta has 15 simple but comfortable studios, and eight two-floor apartments, all with balconies, and the best ones with sea views. (0030 27210 77026; villakosta.com ; two-person studio from €65). Voulas Vacation Houses €€ Set in a garden with orange, lemon and olive trees, these four lovely natural stone cottages come with tile floors, wooden beamed ceilings and self-catering facilities. Each one has a secluded outdoor eating area, and they lie close to the main beach. (0030 27210 77535; voula-vacationhouses.gr ; small house from €500 per week). • Epirus: the best-kept secret in Greece? Mystra, a fortified Byzantine town built into a steep hillside Photo: AP/FOTOLIA Where to eat Kalogria Directly on the beach, with palms out front and a terrace shaded by white awnings, this informal eatery occupies the ground floor of Kalogria Hotel, and has been serving up tasty homemade Greek taverna fare since 1989. (0030 27210 77479; kalogria-beach.gr ) Liastres On the rocky promontory above Stoupa bay, away from the bustle of the seafront, Liastres’ terrace affords great views down onto the water. Come here for standard Greek dishes, after an aperitif at the neighbouring bar, Enigma, under the same management (0030 27210 78113; enigma-cafe.gr/restaurant-en.htm ) Yesterday & Today In a stone cottage with outdoor tables and a barbecue, this informal eatery serves up traditional Greek dishes with a contemporary twist, as well as home-baked bread and pies, and everything is prepared with their own olive oil. (0030 27210 77535; voula-yesterdayandtoday.gr ) Kardamyli, four miles up the coast, was for many years home to the British travel writer and adventurer Patrick Leigh Fermor Photo: AP/FOTOLIA The inside track Above Kalogria beach stands a bronze bust of Nikos Kazantzakis (1883-1957), authour of Zorba the Greek. Although most of his books are set on Crete, Kazantzakis lived in Stoupa in 1917, and it was here that he met the miner Giorgis Zorbas, the character who inspired the namesake in the book. Did you know? While swimming in Stoupa, you’ll come across some refreshingly icy-cold currents, although the sea is generally warm. These are caused by underwater springs that run down from the Taygetos mountains, and emerge below the sea bed. Telegraphtravel Follow @telegraphtravel
